Her sacrifices were held on May lst in a temple on the Aventine, whereas the rites which Clodius violated were held in a private house. The latter sacri- fice, however, was a public sacrifice (pro populo), because it could only be held in the house of an officiating consul or praetor ur- banus. Caesar, at the time of Clodius' crime, was both pontifex and praetor urbanus (Marq. iii. 332). Thus vanishes Mr. Beesly's incredible hypothesis that Cicero should have told the whole story of the sacrilege without binting that the crime was seven months old. The Senate referred the matter to the Pontifices, who pronounced that sacrilege had been done. So the consuls were directed by the Senate to bring in a bill to hold an inquiry into the matter. Caesar has divorced his wife. The consul Piso, through friendship for Clodius, is doing his best to shelve the bill which he is himself obliged to bring forward by order of the Senate.
